This movie from start to finish is a deliberate contrivance in order to create a basis for Christian propaganda. Religious institutions, dogmas, ideologies, and figures were a frequent topic, but never was the legitimacy or illegitimacy of the existence of any deity ever discussed. This movie is a farce. It's built upon a complete misunderstanding of Nietzschean philosophy, and there is a utter disregard for atheist argument. Any professor who did what this movie suggests would have been fired in violation of FICA. Not only has everything the student argues been answered repeatedly by several past philosophers like Nietzsche, Voltaire, and David Hume, but it has been reinterpreted and furthered by New Atheists such as Dawkins, Hitchens, and Harris. All the arguments against god that are presented are infantile and hardly represent current atheistic argument. None of the atheistic arguments and counter arguments are ever addressed, much less rebuffed. text: Finally, a movie that accurately depicts how many Christians imagine their plight, perceive science and reason as persecution, and view the argument against the existence of god as more of an argument against the morality of god. There are plenty of religious folk in academia, in fact, many universities are Christian institutions. As far as philosophy, I don't think many would argue that you can prove or disprove god, and outside of philosophy, you're not going to deal with the subject of belief except in theological studies.   The whole, "angry at god" atheist is a figment of Christian propaganda. It's an imagined enemy to help make Christians feel righteous in their hatred. Atheists aren't angry at god. We done believe in him. Yes, there are many of us that find the monotheistic religions to be very poor guides to morality, but that is not the grounds on which we base our disbelief. We don't believe, because we find the evidence to appear man-made and unconvincing or non-existent.  Still, most atheists would be more than happy to fight for your right to believe whatever you like. It's state sponsored religious promotion and the denial and perversion of proven science that we are against, and so too should believers. Secularism is for the benefit of everyone, because guess what? If Islam, Mormonism, Scientology, or any other religion becomes hugely popular in the U.S., and we do endorse state sponsored religious displays, your kids will be praying the Qur'an towards Mecca at school, or instead of a nativity scene on public grounds, it might be a statue to L. Ron Hubbard or Joseph Smith.  The colonies learned really early on that meddling in the affairs of religious beliefs and supernatural was nothing but trouble, and ended in the murder (and accidental deaths in jail) of many people during the Salem witch trials. So let's all agree to believe what we want to believe, not step on each other's toes, leave religion out of the official public sphere, and all sides stop making the others out to look like the aggressors, because that would be a propagandistic simplification.
